      85             : //! (Constant) member iterator for a JSON object value
      86             : /*!
      87             :     \tparam Const Is this a constant iterator?
      88             :     \tparam Encoding    Encoding of the value. (Even non-string values need to have the same encoding in a document)
      89             :     \tparam Allocator   Allocator type for allocating memory of object, array and string.
      90             : 
      91             :     This class implements a Random Access Iterator for GenericMember elements
      92             :     of a GenericValue, see ISO/IEC 14882:2003(E) C++ standard, 24.1 [lib.iterator.requirements].
      93             : 
      94             :     \note This iterator implementation is mainly intended to avoid implicit
      95             :         conversions from iterator values to \c NULL,
      96             :         e.g. from GenericValue::FindMember.
      97             : 
      98             :     \note Define \c CEREAL_RAPIDJSON_NOMEMBERITERATORCLASS to fall back to a
      99             :         pointer-based implementation, if your platform doesn't provide
     100             :         the C++ <iterator> header.
     101             : 
     102             :     \see GenericMember, GenericValue::MemberIterator, GenericValue::ConstMemberIterator
     103             :  */

     232             : ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
     233             : // GenericStringRef
     234             : 
     235             : //! Reference to a constant string (not taking a copy)
     236             : /*!
     237             :     \tparam CharType character type of the string
     238             : 
     239             :     This helper class is used to automatically infer constant string
     240             :     references for string literals, especially from \c const \b (!)
     241             :     character arrays.
     242             : 
     243             :     The main use is for creating JSON string values without copying the
     244             :     source string via an \ref Allocator.  This requires that the referenced
     245             :     string pointers have a sufficient lifetime, which exceeds the lifetime
     246             :     of the associated GenericValue.
     247             : 
     248             :     \b Example
     249             :     \code
     250             :     Value v("foo");   // ok, no need to copy & calculate length
     251             :     const char foo[] = "foo";
     252             :     v.SetString(foo); // ok
     253             : 
     254             :     const char* bar = foo;
     255             :     // Value x(bar); // not ok, can't rely on bar's lifetime
     256             :     Value x(StringRef(bar)); // lifetime explicitly guaranteed by user
     257             :     Value y(StringRef(bar, 3));  // ok, explicitly pass length
     258             :     \endcode
     259             : 
     260             :     \see StringRef, GenericValue::SetString
     261             : */
     262             : template<typename CharType>
     263             : struct GenericStringRef {
     264             :     typedef CharType Ch; //!< character type of the string
     265             : 
     266             :     //! Create string reference from \c const character array
     267             : #ifndef __clang__ // -Wdocumentation
     268             :     /*!
     269             :         This constructor implicitly creates a constant string reference from
     270             :         a \c const character array.  It has better performance than
     271             :         \ref StringRef(const CharType*) by inferring the string \ref length
     272             :         from the array length, and also supports strings containing null
     273             :         characters.
     274             : 
     275             :         \tparam N length of the string, automatically inferred
     276             : 
     277             :         \param str Constant character array, lifetime assumed to be longer
     278             :             than the use of the string in e.g. a GenericValue
     279             : 
     280             :         \post \ref s == str
     281             : 
     282             :         \note Constant complexity.
     283             :         \note There is a hidden, private overload to disallow references to
     284             :             non-const character arrays to be created via this constructor.
     285             :             By this, e.g. function-scope arrays used to be filled via
     286             :             \c snprintf are excluded from consideration.
     287             :             In such cases, the referenced string should be \b copied to the
     288             :             GenericValue instead.
     289             :      */
     290             : #endif
     291             :     template<SizeType N>
     292             :     GenericStringRef(const CharType (&str)[N]) CEREAL_RAPIDJSON_NOEXCEPT
     293             :         : s(str), length(N-1) {}
     294             : 
     295             :     //! Explicitly create string reference from \c const character pointer
     296             : #ifndef __clang__ // -Wdocumentation
     297             :     /*!
     298             :         This constructor can be used to \b explicitly  create a reference to
     299             :         a constant string pointer.
     300             : 
     301             :         \see StringRef(const CharType*)
     302             : 
     303             :         \param str Constant character pointer, lifetime assumed to be longer
     304             :             than the use of the string in e.g. a GenericValue
     305             : 
     306             :         \post \ref s == str
     307             : 
     308             :         \note There is a hidden, private overload to disallow references to
     309             :             non-const character arrays to be created via this constructor.
     310             :             By this, e.g. function-scope arrays used to be filled via
     311             :             \c snprintf are excluded from consideration.
     312             :             In such cases, the referenced string should be \b copied to the
     313             :             GenericValue instead.
     314             :      */
     315             : #endif
     316             :     explicit GenericStringRef(const CharType* str)
     317             :         : s(str), length(NotNullStrLen(str)) {}
     318             : 
     319             :     //! Create constant string reference from pointer and length
     320             : #ifndef __clang__ // -Wdocumentation

     322             :         \param len length of the string, excluding the trailing NULL terminator
     323             : 
     324             :         \post \ref s == str && \ref length == len
     325             :         \note Constant complexity.

     327             : #endif

     338             : 
     339             : private:

     344             :

    1963             :     struct String {
    1964             :         SizeType length;
    1965             :         SizeType hashcode;  //!< reserved
    1966             :         const Ch* str;
    1967             :     };  // 12 bytes in 32-bit mode, 16 bytes in 64-bit mode
    1968             : 
    1969             :     // implementation detail: ShortString can represent zero-terminated strings up to MaxSize chars
    1970             :     // (excluding the terminating zero) and store a value to determine the length of the contained
    1971             :     // string in the last character str[LenPos] by storing "MaxSize - length" there. If the string
    1972             :     // to store has the maximal length of MaxSize then str[LenPos] will be 0 and therefore act as
    1973             :     // the string terminator as well. For getting the string length back from that value just use
    1974             :     // "MaxSize - str[LenPos]".
    1975             :     // This allows to store 13-chars strings in 32-bit mode, 21-chars strings in 64-bit mode,
    1976             :     // 13-chars strings for CEREAL_RAPIDJSON_48BITPOINTER_OPTIMIZATION=1 inline (for `UTF8`-encoded strings).
    1977             :     struct ShortString {
    1978             :         enum { MaxChars = sizeof(static_cast<Flag*>(0)->payload) / sizeof(Ch), MaxSize = MaxChars - 1, LenPos = MaxSize };
    1979             :         Ch str[MaxChars];
    1980             : 
    1981             :         inline static bool Usable(SizeType len) { return                       (MaxSize >= len); }
    1982     1247738 :         inline void     SetLength(SizeType len) { str[LenPos] = static_cast<Ch>(MaxSize -  len); }
    1983             :         inline SizeType GetLength() const       { return  static_cast<SizeType>(MaxSize -  str[LenPos]); }
    1984             :     };  // at most as many bytes as "String" above => 12 bytes in 32-bit mode, 16 bytes in 64-bit mode
    1985             : 
    1986             :     // By using proper binary layout, retrieval of different integer types do not need conversions.
    1987             :     union Number {
    1988             : #if CEREAL_RAPIDJSON_ENDIAN == CEREAL_RAPIDJSON_LITTLEENDIAN
    1989             :         struct I {
    1990             :             int i;
    1991             :             char padding[4];

    1993             :         struct U {
    1994             :             unsigned u;

    1999             :             char padding[4];

    2001             :         }i;
    2002             :         struct U {
    2003             :             char padding2[4];

    2006             : #endif

    2122             : //! A document for parsing JSON text as DOM.
    2123             : /*!
    2124             :     \note implements Handler concept
    2125             :     \tparam Encoding Encoding for both parsing and string storage.

    2127             :     \tparam StackAllocator Allocator for allocating memory for stack during parsing.
    2128             :     \warning Although GenericDocument inherits from GenericValue, the API does \b not provide any virtual functions, especially no virtual destructor.  To avoid memory leaks, do not \c delete a GenericDocument object via a pointer to a GenericValue.
    2129             : */
